newsitem.title: MEXICO: Famed forensic expert joins Raul Salinas defense.
newsitem.headline: Famed forensic expert joins Raul Salinas defense.

text.p: A leading forensics expert has joined the defence team of Raul Salinas, the jailed brother of disgraced former Mexican President Carlos Salinas, the defence said on Tuesday.

William R. Maples, a forensic anthropologist who has examined the remains of Czar Nicholas II and Joseph Mengele, told a news conference he would attempt to identify remains found buried at Salinas's country home.

"The team that I am putting together will be a team of world-known experts, very similar to the team that I used to examine the remains of Czar Nicholas II in Russia and ... the identification of (former Nazi leader) Joseph Mengele in South America," Maples said.
Raul Salinas is in jail on charges he masterminded a political murder and illegally obtained hundreds of millions of dollars while his brother was in office from 1988 to 1994.
Raul Salinas's legal troubles deepened early this month when skeletal remains were found on one of his ranches, although so far he has not been charged.

Speculation swirled that the body belonged to Manuel Munoz Rocha, a Salinas ally and former congressman who witnesses linked to the 1994 murder of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu who was secretary-general of the ruling party, the PRI.
Raul Salinas is accused of ordering the killing of Ruiz Massieu, his own former brother-in-law. Munoz Rocha has been missing since that murder.
But government experts have ruled out that the remains are of Munoz Rocha, generating a new mystery as to who it is. The defence claims the body was planted on Salinas's property.

Maples, of the C.A. Pound Human Identification Laboratory at the University of Florida, also has worked on several high-profile U.S. cases in recent years such as serial murders and the assassination of civil rights leader Medgar Evers.
Maples said that once he has access to the remains found on Salinas's ranch -- they are still in the hands of federal authorities -- he would attempt identification using the DNA.
"This has nothing to do with international politics," Maples said. "We do the same thing in the United States when DNA is used in identification."
